page.title: 15 CUDHAM - CHURCH YEW TREES
page.content: On the south side of Cudham Church are two very large and ancient yew trees. The female tree has an opening in the north of her trunk and is hollow. This tree has a trunk radius of up to 2m in some places,and a girth of 9.30 metres at a height of 30 cm above ground. The male tree has a girth of 8.70m at the same height, but bulges to 9 metres at 1 metre above ground. This tree has suffered damage over the years due to heavy falls of snow. The female was planted first around 2,000 years ago, the male may not have been planted until centuries later, but cannot be much less than 1,500 years old. Because of their longevity the yew has often been looked on as a symbol of immortality hence its position in the church. These particular trees are a focal point of the village.
